isis.stitle: TSI 07-07-01 - DPF (Diesel Particulate Filter) Regeneration Switches and Regeneration Warning Lights

subjectgroup.subject: DPF (Diesel Particulate Filter) Regeneration Switches and Regeneration Warning Lights

geninfo.para: Starting with vehicle models produced for sale within the United States that utilize diesel engines manufactured on or after January 1, 2007, the EPA enacted new requirements for reduced emissions. The EPA requires both reduction in NOx and Particulate Matter (PM) emitted from the engine to the atmosphere. Reductions to the allowable Federal Limits for NOx are achieved through improvements within the engine itself, whereas reductions to the (PM) Particulate Matter are achieved through a combination of improvements to the engine and the addition of a Diesel Particulate Filter (DPF), which captures the PM, and through a process called regeneration, which periodically converts the PM to ash. This ash must be cleaned from the (DPF) periodically.
Following are definitions of the terms used in the process of removing PM (Particular Matter) and NOx.
Regeneration: The process of converting the trapped particulate matter within the diesel particulate filter into ash.
Passive Regeneration: The natural process of regeneration where the engine provides sufficient temperature through the exhaust gasses to convert the particulate matter to ash.

Active Regeneration: The process of regeneration where changes to the engine operation are required and handled through the vehicle and engine software to increase the exhaust temperature so the particulate matter can be converted to ash.

Manual Regeneration: The process of regeneration where the operator may request that the vehicle and engine change their state to increase the temperature of the exhaust gasses so the regeneration can occur and convert particulate matter to ash.
DPF Status Lamp:The lamp will communicate to the operator the level of particulate matter (soot) trapped in the diesel particulate filter and the need to manually begin the regeneration process.
High Exhaust System Temperature Indicator: (HEST) The indicator will communicate to the operator the warning that the exhaust gas temperature is elevated due to regeneration.

Parked Regeneration Switch: The operator enabled switch that, under certain circumstances, can request that the engine and vehicle change their operation so that regeneration can begin while the vehicle is stationary.
Inhibit Regeneration Switch: The operator enabled switch that requests regeneration will not begin. (This switch is optional on certain models).

para.emph: Indicator Lamps or Status Indicator Lamps:

geninfo.para: Four indicators are available to assist the operator with understanding the status of the vehicle, engine and DPF. These indicators will communicate when to regenerate the DPF, when the engine is de-rated due to excessive soot load in the DPF and when the temperature of the exhaust gasses are extremely hot.

DPF Status Lamp: The DPF Status Lamp provides information regarding the need to regenerate the DPF. Several levels of status will be available. This lamp will progressively change states from off to solid-on to flashing. When Solid-On or Flashing, it indicates the need for the driver to regenerate the DPF. Used in combination with the Check Engine and Stop Engine Lamps, the DPF Status Lamp will provide feedback to the driver on the following regeneration needed levels:

entry.para: LCD Text Message (Units Built After June 2007)
Drive on highway at highway speeds OR start Parked Regeneration to prevent loss of power.
Pull vehicle safely off roadway and start Parked Regeneration to prevent loss of engine power.
An alarm will beep 5 times every minute while ignition is on.
Exhaust filter is full. Engine performance is LIMITED.

warning.para: Pull vehicle safely off roadway and start Parked Regeneration to prevent engine stopping.

entry.para: An alarm will beep continuously while ignition is on.
A serious engine problem has occurred. Exhaust filter may be overfull. Engine may SHUT DOWN soon.

warning.para: Pull vehicle safely off roadway, turn on flashers, place warning devices, and STOP ENGINE. DO NOT USE PARKED REGENERATION. Call for service.

entry.para: NOTE: If this dash indicator is present the exhaust system is HOT and regeneration is in progress.

geninfo.para: Check Engine Lamp: See level 3 above (yellow Yield Sign). The Check Engine Lamp when lit in conjunction with the DPF Status Lamp indicates that the DPF requires regeneration and that the engine will begin a progressive de-rate to limit the amount of soot contained in the DPF.

Stop Engine Lamp: See level 4 above (red stop sign). The Stop Engine Lamp when lit may indicate that the DPF is full and that immediate vehicle service is required. The engine will have been de-rated and may be abruptly stopped to prevent damage to the DPF. The vehicle must be immediately serviced by a qualified technician.

High Exhaust System Temperature Indicator: The High Exhaust System Temperature Indicator will be lit warning the operator that exhaust gas temperatures are elevated above approximately 400 degrees C. During the time when this indicator is on, the operator must keep the vehicle away from flammable materials and vapors. Indicator only comes on below 5 MPH and when exceeding the 400 degrees C temperature.
Switches:

para.title: Parked Regeneration Switch: HPV 3000, 4000, 7000, and 8000 Models

warning.para: Failure to perform a Parked Regeneration when exhaust filter Indicator (level 2) is ON will cause the engine to lose power and eventually shut down.

When performing Parked Regeneration, make certain vehicle is safely off roadway and away from people, or any flammable materials or structures, as the regeneration process will result in elevated exhaust temperatures.
Failure to follow these instructions may result in a loss of engine power, vehicle speed, and may cause an accident or fire resulting in property damage personal injury, or death.

geninfo.para: Perform the following steps to initiate Parked Regeneration (cleaning) of the exhaust DPF:

item.para: Park the vehicle safely off the roadway and away from flammable materials and vapors.
Before initiating parked regeneration (using the ON/PARKD REGEN switch), the following conditions must be in place:
Transmission must be in Neutral (N) or Park (P), if available
Accelerator, foot brake and clutch (if present) pedals must not be depressed,
Engine coolant temperature must be 160 degrees F. or above.
Press the ON position of the ON/PARKD REGEN switch (Figure 1) to initiate the regeneration cycle.

The engine speed will automatically ramp up to a preset RPM and the switch indicator will illuminate when the cycle is started. If the indicator is blinking, check to be sure that all conditions in step 2 have been met. Allow one minute for engine to respond. If indicator cycle switch is still blinking, cycle switch. Once started, the regeneration cycle will last approximately 20 minutes.

para.emph: NOTE: If any of the above conditions are altered during the Parked Regeneration process, regeneration will be halted, and must be restarted.

item.para: When the regeneration cycle is complete, the switch indicator will go off, the engine rpm will return to normal idle and all exhaust filter indicators will be off. The vehicle may now be driven normally.

note.para: In the event of an emergency situation where the vehicle must be moved after beginning Parked Regeneration, press PARKD REGEN position of the ON/PARKD REGEN switch to cancel Parked Regeneration.

warning.para: Failure to perform a Parked Regeneration when exhaust filter Indicator level 2 is ON will cause the engine to lose power and eventually shutdown.

When performing Parked Regeneration, make certain vehicle is safely off roadway and away from people, or any flammable materials or structures, as the regeneration process will result in elevated exhaust temperatures.
Failure to follow these instructions may result in a loss of engine power, vehicle speed, and may cause an accident or fire resulting in property damage personal injury, or death.

geninfo.para: Use the PARKD REGEN ON/CANCEL switch to initiate Parked Regeneration (cleaning) of the exhaust DPF. The PARKD REGEN switch is a momentary three position, center stable switch (Figure 2).

item.para: Park the vehicle safely off the roadway and away from flammable materials and vapors.
Before initiating Parked Regeneration, the following conditions must be in place:
Transmission must be in Neutral (N) or Park (P), if available
Accelerator, foot brake and clutch (if present) pedals must not be depressed,
Engine coolant temperature must be 160 degrees F. or above.
Momentarily press the ON position of the PARKD REGEN ON/CANCEL switch to initiate the regeneration cycle.
The engine speed will automatically ramp up to a preset RPM when the cycle is started. Once started, the regeneration cycle will last approximately 20 minutes.

para.emph: NOTE: If any of the above conditions are not met, the Regeneration process will not be initiated.
NOTE: If any of the above conditions are altered during the Parked Regeneration process, regeneration will be halted, and must be restarted.

item.para: When the regeneration cycle is complete, the engine rpm will return to normal idle and all exhaust filter indicators will turn off. The vehicle may now be driven normally.

note.para: In the event of an emergency situation where the vehicle must be moved after beginning Parked Regeneration, press the CANCEL position of the PARKD REGEN ON/CANCEL switch to cancel Parked Regeneration.

para.title: Inhibit Regeneration Switch: HPV 3000, 4000, 7000, and 8000 Models (this switch is optional on certain models)

geninfo.para: The Regeneration Inhibit switch is used to prevent the Active Regeneration or Parked Regeneration processes.

note.para: There are two versions of the Regeneration Inhibit switch: the two position and the three position switch. Therefore, it's necessary to verify which version is installed in the vehicle. Both versions have the same switch labels.

geninfo.para: With the two position switch, pressing the ON position of the ON/INHIBT REGEN switch will inhibit both Active and Parked Regeneration. Regeneration will be inhibited (latched) when in this position and the switch indicator is turned on.

The three position switch is a momentary switch with a center stable. Pressing the ON position inhibits Active Regeneration while the engine is running, and is reset when the ignition switch is turned Off. The Inhibit function is cancelled when the lower position is pressed, or Parked Regeneration is initiated (PARKD REGEN switch is turned to the ON position).
The switch indicator will be turned on whenever Regeneration Inhibit is enabled.
The Regeneration Inhibit switch is used to prevent the Active Regeneration or Parked Regeneration processes.

note.para: There are two versions of the Regeneration Inhibit switch: the two position INHIBT REGEN ON/OFF switch; and the three position INHIBT REGEN ON/CANCEL switch.

geninfo.para: With the two position switch, selecting the ON position of the INHIBT REGEN ON/OFF switch will inhibit both Active and Parked Regeneration. Regeneration will be inhibited (latched) until the OFF position is selected.

The three position switch is a momentary switch with a center stable. Momentarily pressing the ON position inhibits Active Regeneration while the engine is running, and is reset when the ignition switch is turned Off. The Inhibit function is cancelled when the CANCEL position is pressed. With this switch, Parked Regeneration can be initiated whenever the (PARKED REGEN switch is turned to the ON position).

Temperature Effects of Regeneration: In order to effectively regenerate the DPF, the soot that it stores must be burned at temperatures on the order of 500-600 degrees C. Many operators may not have had experience with exhaust temperatures of this magnitude, especially in a parked vehicle condition. The High Exhaust System Temperature (HEST) indicator is used to notify the operator of the high temperatures. To not pose a threat to the environment, the operator or the vehicle, care should be taken when choosing a location to start a parked regeneration especially when lamp is illuminated. Vehicles must be parked on clean, dry surfaces away from flammable materials and vapors and away from building structures.

Exhaust Cooling Devices and Heat Shields: Many exhaust configurations have been equipped with heat shields and other special devices used to cool the exhaust gasses as they exit the vehicle. These exhaust cooling devices have been added not only for the safety of the operator, but for pedestrians and any potentially flammable materials that may either come in contact with the exhaust system itself, or that the exhaust gasses may come in contact with. These devices use the cooler air outside of the exhaust to mix with the exhaust gasses before they exit the vehicle to the atmosphere. The result is a cooler stream of gasses exiting than would exist without the device. Care should be taken, even with these devices installed on the vehicle that regenerations are done over surfaces that can withstand high heat, that no flammable debris, materials or vapors are in the area around the exhaust and that no pedestrians or operators come in contact with the exhaust system or exhaust gasses during a regeneration or for a period of ten minutes after the regeneration has completed. The exhaust system will remain hot during regeneration and for a period after the regeneration has completed. Use caution when working around the vehicle.

For safety reasons, it is very important that the complete exhaust system not be modified in any way. See G-Letter G2481 guidelines for modifications allowed for 2007 model exhaust and the CT-471 Body Builder book.
